medical_history.chief_complaint: Severe angioedema with a swollen tongue.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient's symptoms began acutely, presenting with swelling of the tongue and moderate dyspnea and dysphagia. Symptoms worsened after initial treatment and were treated with multiple pharmacological interventions over the course of several hours. After treatment including C1-esterase inhibitor and tranexamic acid, the angioedema stopped progressing after 30 minutes, began to decrease 1 hour later, and resolved completely after 36 hours.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient has a 3-year history of type 2 diabetes, treated with metformin until three months ago when sitagliptin was added. He has a past medical history of two episodes of spontaneous lipedema 15 and 30 years ago, which resolved without specific treatment. No other relevant past medical conditions were specified.
medical_history.family_history: The patient's 27-year-old daughter has a heterozygous Thr328Lys mutation in the gene for coagulation factor XII and has developed recurrent angioedema.
medical_history.social_history: The patient is a current cigarette smoker.
